ETYMOLOGY: From Middle English grete, from Old English great ('big, large, tall, thick, coarse'), ultimately from Proto-Germanic *grautaz.

MEANINGS.DEF_EN: Of an extent, amount, or intensity considerably above the average; highly admirable, important, or excellent.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 极好的；优秀的；令人满意的。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: That was a great movie; I highly recommend it.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 那是一部很棒的电影；我强烈推荐。

MEANINGS.DEF_EN: Of much more than average size or intensity; large.
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: We need a great deal of effort to finish this project on time.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 我们需要付出巨大的努力才能按时完成这个项目。

MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 伟大的；杰出的；享有盛名的。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: Marie Curie is considered one of the great scientific minds of the 20th century.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 居里夫人被认为是20世纪最伟大的科学头脑之一。

MEANINGS.DEF_EN: Used to denote a degree of relationship one generation removed from that specified.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 表示隔代的（如曾祖父或曾祖母）。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: My great-aunt taught me how to bake bread.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 我的曾姑妈教我如何烤面包。
